message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness along with tenderness over the lung suggests an acute condition. The history of smoking increases the risk for thromboembolism, and the chest CT scan showing a wedged-shaped, pleura-based triangular area of hemorrhage in the right lower lobe is most indicative of embolism. Pulmonary atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis are not typically associated with acute symptoms such as those described here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a pulmonary embolism, which can cause sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness. The fact that the patient had surgery and is a smoker also increases the risk for embolism. The CT scan also shows a triangular area of hemorrhage, which is commonly seen in pulmonary infarction caused by embolism. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are less likely causes in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, along with a history of smoking and recent surgery, suggests the most probable cause of the pulmonary lesion is embolism. Thrombosis would be a possible cause but it is less likely because the chest pain increases with deep inspiration, indicating pleuritic chest pain, which is associated with embolism. Pulmonary atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis may cause chronic lung disease but they do not present with acute symptoms like chest pain and breathlessness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, along with the patient’s smoking history and recent surgery, suggest pulmonary embolism as the most probable cause of the pulmonary lesion. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are less likely causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, along with the patient's history of smoking and recent hip replacement, indicate a possible pulmonary embolism. The CT scan showed a pleura-based triangular area of hemorrhage in the right lower lobe of the lung, which is consistent with a pulmonary infarction caused by an embolus. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are not likely to cause this specific pattern of pulmonary hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, along with the recent hip replacement and smoking history, suggests pulmonary embolism as the most probable cause of the pulmonary lesion. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are not likely to cause sudden symptoms like this.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, along with the patient's history of smoking and recent hip replacement, raise the suspicion of a pulmonary embolism. The focal, wedged-shaped lesion seen on the chest CT scan is also consistent with this diagnosis. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are less likely to cause this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness with tenderness over the lung and a CT scan showing a wedge-shaped lesion suggest a pulmonary embolism, which is commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis in patients who have had recent surgery and are at risk due to smoking and hypertension. The other options do not match the symptoms or risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has had recent surgery and a history of smoking, which puts her at risk for pulmonary embolism. The sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness along with a CT scan showing a pleura-based area of hemorrhage in the lung suggest a pulmonary embolism as the most likely cause. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are less likely causes in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of smoking, recent surgery, sudden onset of chest pain and breathlessness, and a pulmonary lesion on CT scan. These are all suggestive of pulmonary embolism, which can cause hemorrhage and infarction of lung tissue. Thrombosis, pulmonary atherosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis are not likely causes of the pulmonary lesion in this case.
